title: U.S. News:  U.S. Watch
text:
ALABAMA

Dobbs Cited to Back

Transgender Law

Alabama's attorney general is defending the state's ban on medical treatments for transgender youth by citing the U.S. Supreme Court's decision overturning Roe v. Wade.

The state's attorney general's office, led by Republican Steve Marshall, submitted a brief Monday asking a federal appeals court to remove an injunction blocking Alabama from enforcing the law, which bans surgery and other gender-affirming treatments such as hormones and puberty blockers for those who are under 19 years old.

The attorney's general office made several citations of Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization. "But no one -- adult or child -- has a right to transitioning treatments that is deeply rooted in our Nation's history and tradition," the attorney general's office wrote in the brief. "The State can thus regulate or prohibit those interventions for children, even if an adult wants the drugs for his child."

Jennifer Levi, the transgender rights project director for GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders, said she wasn't surprised to see Alabama relying on Dobbs to defend its ban on transgender medical treatments for children.

"We don't think, however, Alabama's use of Dobbs will gain much traction with the appeals court because the Supreme Court majority was so clear that the opinion has no application beyond abortion," she said.

-- Joseph De Avila

WASHINGTON, D.C.

Medal of Freedom

Recipients Named

President Biden selected more than a dozen people to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom, including gymnast Simone Biles, the late Apple Inc. leader Steve Jobs, actor and director Denzel Washington and the late Sen. John McCain. The awards, the country's highest civilian honor, will be presented July 7 at the White House.

"These 17 Americans demonstrate the power of possibilities and embody the soul of the nation -- hard work, perseverance, and faith," the White House said Friday. Mr. Biden himself received the Medal of Freedom in 2017, from President Barack Obama.

The other recipients are: Sister Simone Campbell, the former executive director of the Catholic social-justice organization Network; Julieta Garcia, the first Hispanic woman to serve as a college president; former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords (D., Ariz.) who became a gun-control advocate after being gravely wounded in a 2011 shooting; Fred Gray, a lawyer who represented both Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks; Father Alexander Karloutsos, former vicar general of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America; Khizr Khan, Constitution Literacy and National Unity Center founder and Gold Star father; Sandra Lindsay, a critical-care nurse who was the first American to get a Covid-19 vaccine outside of clinical trials; Diane Nash, civil-rights campaign organizer; Megan Rapinoe, Olympic gold medalist in soccer and Women's World Cup winner; Alan Simpson, Republican former U.S. senator from Wyoming; the late Richard Trumka, former president of the AFL-CIO; Wilma Vaught, among the most decorated women in U.S. military history; and Raul Yzaguirre, former National Council of La Raza president and chief executive.

-- Allison Prang

TEXAS

Suspect in Cyclist's

Slaying Is Arrested

The woman suspected of fatally shooting an elite cyclist in May was arrested in Costa Rica after 43 days on the run, according to police and federal authorities.

Police in Austin, Texas, had named Kaitlin Marie Armstrong a suspect in the May 11 death of Anna Moriah Wilson, a 25-year-old rising star in the off-road biking community.

Ms. Wilson, a Vermont native, had traveled to Austin to compete in a race, according to the U.S. Marshals Service. A friend found her bleeding and unresponsive inside a home, the Austin police said. She had multiple gunshot wounds and was pronounced dead at the scene.

Officers from the U.S. Marshals Service, the Homeland Security Department and the State Department, working with authorities in Costa Rica, located and arrested Ms. Armstrong on Wednesday at a hostel on a Costa Rica beach, the agency said. The 34-year-old was set to be deported to the U.S., the agency said.

-- Alyssa Lukpat
